image.altText: Collins gestures with one hand while speaking at the despatch box in the House of Representatives.

items.synopsis: The federal government has left open the option of pursuing housing options that will be met with less resistance, after failing to pass its signature $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund.

title.children: Housing minister won't rule out dumping signature $10b fund in favour of easier paths to building housing

image.altText: Aerial shot lookingn straight down at big battery project under construction

items.synopsis: One of the world's biggest renewable energy providers is increasing its stakes in Australia after receiving approval to build a multi-billion-dollar battery in Western Australia's coal heartlands.

title.children: French green energy giant doubles down on Australia with mega WA battery

image.altText: A dark skinned man with a baseball cap and a serious expression

items.synopsis: At a youth centre in Perth's eastern suburbs where Cassius Turvey could often be found, a place that helps stop children from falling through the cracks, the teenager's absence is still being sorely felt.

title.children: Ray Tanielu knew Cassius Turvey and his friends well. Eight months on from the teenager's death, he's seen a change

image.altText: A trial field of cannabis growing in Queensland.

items.synopsis: The Legalise Cannabis party says the move to reform cannabis legislation will help shift Australians out of the criminal justice system.

title.children: Bills to be introduced in three states to legalise cannabis for personal use

image.altText: A composite image of two men and a woman, separated by paper tears.

items.synopsis: Across Australia, more than 46,000 clients under state control are prevented by law from being identified, but there are growing calls for change. Some say gag laws that were designed to protect vulnerable people are shielding the agencies involved from scrutiny.

title.children: Memories sent to the tip, refused money for Christmas — and all by order of the state

image.altText: A chaotic scene with several people on the ground in a hospital, all of them with blurred faces.

items.synopsis: An expert in medical law warns WA health workers they need to be aware they can not legally keep someone in hospital if they do not want to be there.

title.children: Warning for WA health workers over keeping patients in hospital against their will

image.altText: An image of the Reserve bank sign in Martin Place, Sydney

items.synopsis: Minutes from this month's RBA board meeting show interest rates were almost kept steady this month.

title.children: Reserve Bank almost left interest rates on hold this month

image.altText: Baby Jarrod at time of second visit to Caboolture hospital in October 2022. The child has a rash around his mouth and face

items.synopsis: Baby Jarrod was in "absolute agony" when his parents took him to the emergency department two days in a row. He only received a diagnosis when his father called in Ryan's Rule.

title.children: Baby in 'absolute agony' turned away days after assurances hospital was providing best possible care

image.altText: A small submersible plunging into the water.

items.synopsis: Deep in the waters of the Atlantic Ocean, a search is underway for a submersible that was carrying five people when it disappeared on an expedition to the wreckage of the Titanic.

title.children: Frantic search as Titanic submersible disappears underwater with five people and 96 hours' oxygen

image.altText: Close up of red and green numbers on ASX board

items.synopsis: The local share market rises to a fresh seven-week high, while the Australian dollar slips after the Reserve Bank releases its June meeting minutes, detailing its worries of inflation becoming entrenched in the economy.

title.children: Minutes show RBA lifted rates on fears of entrenched inflation, Aussie dollar slips

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Deputy RBA governor Michele Bullock begins her speech telling the audience that while the central bank has been focused on combatting combat high inflation, they are still focused on its other objective — full employment. "But just because our inflation objective has been in focus recently, it does not mean that the other part of our mandate – maintaining full employment – has become any less important," she says. "Full employment is, and has always been, one of our two main objectives. "When discussing full employment, in the context of a central bank’s mandate, economists typically talk about the non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment – the NAIRU. I will come back to this concept. "But, more generally, full employment means that people who want a job can find one without having to search for too long. As I will emphasise later, the number of hours of work that people can secure is also important in defining full employment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Maintaining full employment is still RBA's focus despite inflation fight

children.content: Deputy RBA governor Michele Bullock begins her speech telling the audience that while the central bank has been focused on combatting combat high inflation, they are still focused on its other objective — full employment.
"But just because our inflation objective has been in focus recently, it does not mean that the other part of our mandate – maintaining full employment – has become any less important," she says.
"Full employment is, and has always been, one of our two main objectives.

"When discussing full employment, in the context of a central bank’s mandate, economists typically talk about the non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment – the NAIRU. I will come back to this concept.

"But, more generally, full employment means that people who want a job can find one without having to search for too long. As I will emphasise later, the number of hours of work that people can secure is also important in defining full employment."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: She's addressing the Ai Group, with a speech titled "Achieving Full Employment". She's also speaking after the RBA's minutes of its June meeting were released.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA deputy governor Michele Bullock is speaking in Newcastle

children.content: She's addressing the Ai Group, with a speech titled "Achieving Full Employment".
She's also speaking after the RBA's minutes of its June meeting were released.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Woodside Energy said it has approved the development of the $US7.2 billion ($10.5b) Trion ultra deepwater oil project in the Gulf of Mexico, which is expected to provide a strong and quick return on investment. Woodside (which is the 60% owner and operator of Trion) forecast its share of the capital expenditure at $US4.8 billion. The remainder is set to be funded by Mexican state-owned oil company Pemex, which owns 40% of Trion. The resource will be developed through a floating production unit (FPU) with an oil production capacity of 100,000 barrels per day, Woodside said. First production is targeted for 2028. The investment is expected to deliver an internal rate of return greater than 16% with a payback period of less than four years, Woodside said. Woodside, which has frequently found itself at the crosshairs of environmental groups and activist investors over their climate goals, said their greenhouse gas emissions reduction targets remain unchanged by the investment decision. Shares of the country's biggest independent oil and gas producer were up 2.1%, against a 0.7% gain in the broader market. The Australasian Centre for Corporate Responsibility (ACCR) was critical of Woodside's investment decision. “Trion will be a carbon emissions bomb, representing a 14% increase against Woodside’s current estimated emissions," said Alex Hillman, lead analyst at ACCR. “This decision tells investors exactly what Woodside is as a company: a pure play oil and gas producer denying that the world is decarbonising and without a credible transition strategy. “Woodside even states that Trion’s returns will be used to fund new oil and gas projects, indicating that no end is in sight for its hydrocarbon expansion plans." BHP, from whom the project was inherited, was aiming for a final decision on Trion in 2022 before its petroleum assets were merged with Woodside. But rising costs for manufacturing components for mega projects worldwide led to delays. Trion was discovered by Pemex in 2012. It is located at Mexico's Perdido basin, about 180 km off the Mexican coastline at a depth of 2,500 metres. Development of the project remains subject to regulatory approvals.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woodside goes ahead with $10.5b Trion oil project in Mexico

children.content: Woodside Energy said it has approved the development of the $US7.2 billion ($10.5b) Trion ultra deepwater oil project in the Gulf of Mexico, which is expected to provide a strong and quick return on investment.
Woodside (which is the 60% owner and operator of Trion) forecast its share of the capital expenditure at $US4.8 billion.
The remainder is set to be funded by Mexican state-owned oil company Pemex, which owns 40% of Trion.
The resource will be developed through a floating production unit (FPU) with an oil production capacity of 100,000 barrels per day, Woodside said. First production is targeted for 2028.
The investment is expected to deliver an internal rate of return greater than 16% with a payback period of less than four years, Woodside said.

Woodside, which has frequently found itself at the crosshairs of environmental groups and activist investors over their climate goals, said their greenhouse gas emissions reduction targets remain unchanged by the investment decision.
Shares of the country's biggest independent oil and gas producer were up 2.1%, against a 0.7% gain in the broader market.
The Australasian Centre for Corporate Responsibility (ACCR) was critical of Woodside's investment decision.
“Trion will be a carbon emissions bomb, representing a 14% increase against Woodside’s current estimated emissions," said Alex Hillman, lead analyst at ACCR.
“This decision tells investors exactly what Woodside is as a company: a pure play oil and gas producer denying that the world is decarbonising and without a credible transition strategy.
“Woodside even states that Trion’s returns will be used to fund new oil and gas projects, indicating that no end is in sight for its hydrocarbon expansion plans."

BHP, from whom the project was inherited, was aiming for a final decision on Trion in 2022 before its petroleum assets were merged with Woodside. But rising costs for manufacturing components for mega projects worldwide led to delays.

Trion was discovered by Pemex in 2012. It is located at Mexico's Perdido basin, about 180 km off the Mexican coastline at a depth of 2,500 metres. Development of the project remains subject to regulatory approvals.

image.altText: Black and white photograph of a man playing the guitar with long hair

items.synopsis: Crispin Dye's case which was due to be revisited today at an inquiry has now been delayed after a judge described NSW Police record keeping as "borderline shambolic".

title.children: New evidence about brutal death of AC/DC manager uncovered during gay hate inquiry

image.altText: A sign post with pathways saying Yes and No against a blue sky

items.synopsis: For the first time in 24 years, Australians are heading to the polls to decide on a change to the constitution. Legislation setting up a referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament passed the Senate on Monday, meaning a referendum has to be held before the end of the year.

title.children: It's official — the Voice referendum is happening. Here's what comes next

image.altText: Three people stand in blizzard at Mount Hotham.

items.synopsis: A polar air mass sends the mercury plunging over south-eastern Australia on Tuesday and Wednesday, while a thick rain band is brewing in the north-west and set to deliver falls across the country by the end of the week.

title.children: South-eastern Australia to shiver through prolonged frosty weather, with 'tropical' rain on the way

image.altText: A collage of black and white images of a man smiling in a suit and tie, holding a rifle, and in a passport-style photo.

items.synopsis: The untold spy story of a mole in ASIO's ranks who sold the Soviets highly classified intelligence and got away with it.

title.children: By the time Australia's spy agency learned one of its officers was a KGB mole he was retired and playing golf

image.altText: Putin says he may seize 'buffer zone' in Ukraine

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin has a brutal new strategy to ensure Russia's invasion of Ukraine is "a long process". It means there are now strategic and humanitarian imperatives for the West to defeat Putin's latest theory of victory, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Vladimir Putin's plan to win quickly in Ukraine failed. Russia is now implementing an even more brutal strategy

image.altText: A woman in a pool holding on to the edge

items.synopsis: While not quite as high profile as the looming Voice referendum, Collie woman Silvia Chiera hopes a local vote on whether to build an indoor pool will deliver a community-shaping result.

title.children: Why this WA community will vote in two referendums this year

image.altText: Pat Cummins clenches fists and yells in delight as Ben Stokes walks off behind him

items.synopsis: Australia has raised eyebrows with its anti-Bazball measures in the first Ashes Test at Edgbaston, but all the spread fields and conservative bowling could yet add up to a famous win.

title.children: Australia and England follow different paths to meet for a thrilling climax to Edgbaston Test

image.altText: Steve Smith rolls on the ground

items.synopsis: England started day four of the first Ashes Test with a wild reverse ramp from Joe Root, and never looked back on a thrilling day of Test cricket. Here's the five things you missed overnight.

title.children: Five quick hits — Root's unorthodox batting raises eyebrows and Bairstow lets Khawaja off

image.altText: A woman wearing a white turtle neck and black blazer stands smiling in a restaurant.

items.synopsis: North Korea's "Jangmadang Generation" grew up facing immense hardship after a devastating famine. Now those fortunate few who escaped find the skills they used to survive rather helpful in capitalist South Korea.

title.children: Chan Yang built a thriving secret business in North Korea. Then she made a daring bid for freedom

image.altText: vehicles lined up next to each other with black and white logos

items.synopsis: The truck, carrying $10,000 of fresh meat, went on to damage about 30 vehicles as it was driven down the Bruce Highway. The alleged thief had also stopped by a few hardware stores to buy paint in a bid to conceal the truck's logos.

title.children: 'This blew us away, the power of social media': Online sleuths help locate butcher shop truck stolen in brazen heist

image.altText: A hundred people gathering next to a paddock and listing to a man speak who is standing on a ute.

items.synopsis: Albermale's 500-person facility was given the green light by state planning authorities, but remained fiercely opposed by Binningup residents.

title.children: US lithium giant abolishes plans for workers' camp in WA coastal town following backlash

image.altText: Greig Pickhaver aka HG Nelson wearing a navy blue collared shirt and smiling at David Wenham, who's sitting opposite him

items.synopsis: He's one half of much-loved comedy duo Roy and HG, but Greig Pickhaver says a diagnosis of dyslexia was both a "blessing and a curse" as he carved out a successful career "making up things on the spot".

title.children: Greig 'HG Nelson' Pickhaver on why planning out life is 'a complete crock'

image.altText: A clothing store in Sydney advertises for staff in its shopfront.

items.synopsis: While economic growth is slowing, the jobs market hasn't been this strong since the 1950s. Unemployment is plumbing half century lows — a development that has everyone from central banks to politicians scratching their heads, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Interest rates aren't working in the way we thought they would and it's not clear why

image.altText: Women in black shirt holding flyer looks sad

items.synopsis: Carrie-Ann Adams's symptoms were mistaken for the flu — but in reality, she was dying of bowel cancer and had 12 weeks to live.

title.children: Ann says lowering the bowel cancer screening age could have saved her 41yo daughter's life

image.altText: A man in a suit is pictured walking holding his phone up to his ear, he is surrounded by big grey buildings in Beijing CBD.

items.synopsis: From cutting salaries and bonuses and asking staff not to wear expensive clothes and watches at work, to reining in travel and entertainment expenses, Chinese financial firms have jumped on an austerity drive as Beijing pushes to bridge the wealth gap.

title.children: No more flashy clothes, designer bags or five-star hotels: Chinese bankers told to rein in expenses in austerity drive

image.altText: A young woman with long blonde hair stands outside, wearing a white jumper and holding books unde rher arm

items.synopsis: Jasmine didn’t have a parental figure to help her navigate the tax system or buy household basics. But she's pleased other teens in foster care may soon have support for longer under law reform promised across the country.

title.children: After going through 'dark days' when she left foster care at 18, Jasmin is studying to become a paramedic

image.altText: Bill Shorten

items.synopsis: The actions of Australia's politicians in parliament come under fire on Q+A after a week that saw David Van leave the Liberals and Katy Gallagher grilled by the Coalition.

title.children: 'Toxic': Shorten takes aim at behaviour of politicians in parliament

image.altText: Ukrainian soldiers hold up yellow-and-blue national flags.

items.synopsis: Ukraine says it has made another gain in its counteroffensive, driving Russian forces out of the village of Piatykhatky, which is significant for being near the most direct route to the Azov Sea coast.

title.children: Ukraine claims eight villages now retaken, with 'biggest blow' in offensive yet to come

image.altText: Man wearing black t-shirt stands on balcony with ocean in the background, folding his arms.

items.synopsis: The International Transport Workers' Federation says inspections of boats at NSW ports raise serious concerns about pay and conditions.

title.children: Union says 'modern slavery' must end as seafarer wage crackdown finds $4 million owed to workers

image.altText: Bottlenose dolphin calf Dusty swims with mum Jinx at Sea World on the Gold Coast

items.synopsis: The UN has adopted the world's first treaty to protect the high seas and preserve marine biodiversity in international waters, marking a milestone after nearly 20 years of effort, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres announced Monday.

title.children: UN adopts world's first treaty to protect marine biodiversity
